dt: {bc}to make unclean or impure: such as
{bc}to corrupt the purity or perfection of {bc}{sx|debase||}
{bc}to violate the chastity or virginity of {bc}{sx|deflower||}
{bc}to make physically unclean especially with something unpleasant or contaminating

dt.t: … I had never allowed anyone to smoke in the truck. Drunk as I was, I knew that I was betraying something by allowing him to {wi}defile{/wi} the truck's interior.
went to jail for costuming themselves in the American flag and thus {wi}defiling{/wi} it

pt: {sc}contaminate{/sc} {sc}taint{/sc} {sc}pollute{/sc} {sc}defile{/sc} mean to make impure or unclean. {sc}contaminate{/sc} implies intrusion of or contact with dirt or foulness from an outside source.
{sc}taint{/sc} stresses the loss of purity or cleanliness that follows contamination.

{sc}pollute{/sc}, sometimes interchangeable with {it}contaminate{/it}, distinctively may imply that the process which begins with contamination is complete and that what was pure or clean has been made foul, poisoned, or filthy.
{sc}defile{/sc} implies befouling of what could or should have been kept clean and pure or held sacred and commonly suggests violation or desecration.

pt.t: {it}defile{/it} a hero's memory with slanderous innuendo

et: Middle English, alteration (influenced by {it}filen{/it} to defile, from Old English {it}fȳlan{/it}) of {it}defoilen{/it} to trample, defile, from Anglo-French {it}defoiller, defuler{/it}, to trample, from {it}de-{/it} + {it}fuller, foller{/it} to trample, literally, to full {ma}{mat|full|}{/ma}
shortdef: to make unclean or impure: such as
to corrupt the purity or perfection of : debase
to violate the chastity or virginity of : deflower

dt: {bc}a narrow passage (as between hills, rocks, or cliffs) {bc}{sx|gorge:1||}

dt.t: … come to us from a narrow {wi}defile{/wi} in the Pennine Alps between Switzerland and Italy, a place called the Great St. Bernard Pass.

shortdef: a narrow passage (as between hills, rocks, or cliffs) : gorge

dt.t: … breaks out into a brave and glorious description of the forces, as they {wi}defiled{/wi} through the principal gate of the city …

et: French {it}défiler{/it}, from {it}dé-{/it} de- + {it}filer{/it} to move in a column {ma}{mat|file|}{/ma}
shortdef: to march off in a line
